column4: The first question everyone will ask you when they hear you're engaged is where and when is the wedding. So talk it out: destination wedding or someplace local? Fall or spring?
Tutorial (How-to):
1. Take weather, seasoning, budget into account
2. Focus on what you want your wedding day to be and how to portray that in a date
3. Give yourself plenty of time to plan your dream wedding and don't rush it!
4. Come up with a preferred date and a few alternates

column4: Beside this to-do list, most of your communication with your wedding party and professionals happen through emails.
Tutorial (How-to):
1. Name folders by service categories
2. Drag emails to different folders
3. Keep updated with things

column4: Talk about who will pay for what. You might cover the entire thing or maybe your families will each commit a dollar amount. Just whatever you do, don't spend one dollar until you have a budget.
Tutorial (How-to):
1. Figure out who's paying for the wedding
2. Estimate guest headcount
3. Get aware of a sample budget breakdown: 
     - Reception (Food, Beverages, Rentals, and Site) 40% 
     - Flowers 5-10%
     - Photography/Videography 15% 
     - Bride's and Groom's attire & beauty10%
     - Music 5%
     - Planner or Coordinator 10-15%
     - Miscellaneous (Invitations, Officiant Fees, Favors, Etc.) 10%
     - Cushion 5%

column4: Now it's time to start choosing your wedding party (groan...). This should be an exciting task -- a chance to round up your very favorite people to surround you on the happiest day of your life.
Tutorial (How-to):
1. Wait to ask until you've set your wedding date. Adding bridesmaids is a lot more fun than demoting them.
2. Don't feel like you have to include all the siblings
3. Have "bridesmen" and "groomsgirls", if you'd like to give your bro an important role.
4. Redefine the roles and number.  If you want to have 2 "maids" or 3 "matrons" or no one "of honor," do what works for you
5. Ask other friends and relatives to act as candlelighters, ushers, etc

column4: It's not required but consider hiring one if you: want a destination wedding, have a busy job, or like the idea of a third person (expert) opinion. Sound like you? Research and set up interviews.
Tutorial (How-to):
1. Ask friends if they can recommend some 
2. Research online to find 5 finalists to schedule a talk by phone or in-person
3. Interview them with the questions, i.e. “How do you communicate with clients?”;“How many clients do you have in a year, and in my wedding month?”;“Do you work alone or with a team?”;“What additional fees do I need to know about?”

column4: Finish interviewing your top picks, and then make a decision. Your planner's personality and how well you work together should be key. Once you decide, sign the contract and put down a deposit.
Tutorial (How-to):
1. Confirm Insurance coverage, services included and timeline
2. Disucuss rehearsal and other parties around wedding day
3. Schedule payment and sign contract
4. Schedule progress meetings
Resource (separate by comma): What's the difference between a venue coordinator and event coordinator?

column4: Romantic wedding? Think pastels and neutrals. A high-energy party? Go bold. Save your favorite colors to your helpers and they will affect a host of decisions.
Tutorial (How-to):
1.Use your favorite shade. You’ve been in love with pale lavender since the first grade, so this is a good place to begin – with what you love. You can tastefully incorporate any color into your wedding decorations by selecting the right hue, and combining it with the right accents.
2.Consider the setting. Look at the colors used in your venue’s carpeting, drapery and decorations. If the site has strong colors, you’ll need to select a color scheme that complements. If you already have your heart set on a certain color, you may need to select a more neutrally decorated site but this needs to be sorted out very early on or you may miss out on a good location! However, keep an open mind about colors until you've chosen the venue, because the setting may well suggest the color scheme for you.
3.Be prepared to have two different/distinct color themes if your church or wedding building and reception venue are very different in tone. In general, it is probable that you will have more leeway to use colors with the reception than where the wedding ceremony itself is held. However, you can still carry the color theme in clothing and flowers from the place of marriage to the reception, even if you can't decorate the church, town hall, or register office as much as you'd like.
4.Enlist your favorite bloom. If sunflowers are your thing, there’s no reason why they shouldn’t make it into your décor scheme. Incorporate your predominant flower color – either making it the dominant shade or using it as an accent – and it will all come together.

column4: Finalize a date both practical and personal based on your preference and venues.
Tutorial (How-to):
1. Check with the top-tier guests
2. Check with venues and your most important service professionals
3. Double check the no-no days, i.e. the weekend before tax day
4. Think about the time of day. Evening events are formal

column4: Before you head down to the clerk's office, check out their website. Most counties won't let you apply for your marriage license more than a week or two before the wedding day.
Tutorial (How-to):
1. Find your marriage license office
2. Make a reservation
3. After the wedding, your officiant will send your signed license to the marriage license bureau, and then you should receive a certified copy within a few weeks or months (depending on your state).

column4: Make sure you're all paid up with your vendors (that, or you have an agreement as to when the final payments will come in). You don't want it hanging over your head on the honeymoon!
Tutorial (How-to):
1. Review your contract to determine when the balance will be due
2. Include a gratuity, if it is not already included in the price ($30-50)

column4: This is critical especially if you don't have a wedding planner to do it for you. Take your time and be thorough with the details. Then send it out to the bridal party and make lots of extra copies!
Tutorial (How-to):
1. Get the team together in person and go through everything
2. Send them the to-do list parts and make sure they've read it
3. Confirm any VIP toasts

column4: Obsessed with the way your cake turned out? Couldn't have done it without your planner? Rate your wedding vendors so that other brides know who to hire.
Tutorial (How-to):
1. Upload your stunning photos to "Lady Marry"
2. Review your pros and share your comments to help the coming brides-to-be

column4: If you belong to a house of worship, ask about open dates and pricing. If that’s not the case, then start your search right here. Find a few places you like, and then schedule time to take a tour.
Tutorial (How-to):
1. Browse ideas
2. Discuss, negotiate, and decide on a place where both of you will love
3. Schedule appointments with sites and/or officiant
4. Check space of seated and standing
5. Ask if the site has any restriction, i.e. will the officiant need a microphone, outside musicians

column4: Start your search online -- look at photos and read reviews. Then, narrow it down to a handful of your favorites and call to set up site tours. When you're there, ask lots of questions.
Tutorial (How-to):
1. Browse ideas
2. Discuss, negotiate, and check the site coordinator's responsibilities
3. Schedule appointments with sites

column4: This is a biggie! First, request a contract. Then read through it very carefully. If you have questions, ask. You should be absolutely comfortable with the contract before you sign the dotted line
Tutorial (How-to):
1. Check the prices and the items/services included
2. Check insurance policy and suggestions for plan B
3. Confirm the rules everyone has to follow, including setup and cleaning hours
4. Confirm the schedule of rehearsal and wedding day
5. Confirm the payment schedule

column4: If it’s a non-religious space, request a contract and put down a deposit. Now is also the time to find out about marriage license requirements (so that you have time to gather necessary documents).
Tutorial (How-to):
1. Check the prices and the items/services included, i.e. overtime charge, rental, and cocktail space
2. Check insurance policy and suggestions for plan B
3. Confirm the rules everyone has to follow, including drinks, parking
4. Confirm the schedule of rehearsal and wedding day
5. Ask how long is the aisle
6. Confirm the payment schedule

column4: When you call to make a reservation, be sure to mention that you're booking the room for your wedding night. You might get a free upgrade.
Choosing the most important - and likely the most expensive - ensemle you'll ever wear takes careful consideration.
Putting a policy on your engagement ring may sound unromantic, but the peace of mind is probably worth it. There are few different ways to do it, so read up below!
Tutorial (How-to):
1. Get an appraisal for your ring
2. Find out if an existing homeowners or rental policy will cover your engagement ring
3. Locate a separate insurance policy for a ring that isn’t or can't be covered under an existing homeowners or rental insurance policy
4. Choose a deductible
5. Document ring photos and other paperwork

column4: It's time to try on those styles you've been saving to your board! So grab your mom or best friend and make appointments at several stores. And give yourselves at least two hours at each store.
Tutorial (How-to):
1. Call shops in advance
2. Be open to different styles 
3. Wear your wedding-day undergarments to shops
4. Buy the size that fits the biggest part of your body
5. Bring a shopping buddy who has your best interest in mind

column4: It's time to try on those styles you've been saving to your board! So grab your mom or best friend and make appointments at several stores. And give yourselves at least two hours at each store.
Tutorial (How-to):
1. Call shops in advance
2. Be open to different styles 
3. Wear your wedding-day undergarments to shops
4. Buy the size that fits the biggest part of your body
5. Bring a shopping buddy who has your best interest in mind

column4: When you envision yourself on wedding day, what do you see? Save hair and makeup ideas to your planner -- pick a variety of options to show your hairstylist and makeup artist during your trials.
Tutorial (How-to): 1. Save makeup & hairstyle photos

column4: You want to give yourself plenty of time to order the dress and then to have alterations and fitting appointments. Once you buy it, you’ll also want to schedule time for your first dress fitting.
Tutorial (How-to):
1. Schedule payment and sign contract
2. Ask delivery time
3. Schedule the first fitting and ask recommendations of undergarments

column4: Once you have a good idea as to how you want them to look, take one or all of your bridesmaids dress shopping. Then make your pick!
Tutorial (How-to):
1. Consider their personal preferences and concerns and your theme color
2. Claify who pay for the attire first
3. Send them color swatches if they select their own dresses

column4: Tuxedos or suits? Decide what you want the guys to wear and how you want them to look. Hint: Usually time, place, and formality are the driving forces behind your choice.
Tutorial (How-to):
1. Make appointments
2. Be open to different styles 
3. Ask tailoring
4. Bring a shopping buddy who has your best interest in mind
5. Confirm delivery and cancellation policy before purchase

column4: You obviously want your hair to look impeccable and match your wedding theme.
Tutorial (How-to):
1. Save and share photos with stylists
2. Tell your allergy history
3. Schedule trials with a few stylists. You can do one on the engagement photo day.
4. Confirm payment scheule and sign the contract

column4: You'll want to give yourselves a couple months to browse, research price and revisit rings that catch your eye.
Tutorial (How-to):
1. Browse all the resources, research price
2. Ask your friends for recommendations

column4: It's a good idea to bring one person (your mom or a friend) along with you for this. That way they can weigh in on how the dress fits you and make you feel more comfortable during the appointment.
Tutorial (How-to):
1. Ask at least one people to come along
2. Bring essentials to the fitting
3. Schedule the next fitting

column4: What you wear under the dress is almost just as important to looking good as the gown itself. Ideally you’ll want to buy before your first fitting.
Tutorial (How-to):
1. Buy essentials for under the dress
2. Ask your wedding party if they also need some

column4: The type of formalwear usually dictates the accessories -- but this is the place to show some style. Find a tie that sets him apart from the and splurge on a great pair of dress shoes.
Tutorial (How-to):
1. Tie
2. Shoes & socks
3. Cuff links
4. Cummerbund / vest

column4: Have a hair trial with your stylist. Don’t forget to bring your wedding veil to make sure it works with your style. You should also finalize your wedding day beauty appointments now.
Tutorial (How-to):
1. Bring anything you might want in your hair to the trial.
2. Estimate the time of design and post-trial lasting time
3. Ask your wedding party if they also need beauty services

column4: The right jewelry and shoes completes the look. So figure out how you want to finish off your look and then buy it before your final dress fitting.
Tutorial (How-to):
1. Headpiece 
2. Veil
3. Shoes
4. Lingerie
5. Garter
6. Gloves
7. Handbag
8. Sashes
9. Jewelry (necklace,earings, bracelet)

column4: Have Your Last Dress Fitting There might be some butterflies at this appointment. It's totally normal! At this point, your dress should fit you nice and tight and all of your accessories should look just right.
Tutorial (How-to):
1. Ask at least one people to come along
2. Schedule the pick-up
3. Arrange post-wedding maintainance

column4: Start with immediate family and friends, then move on to the rest of the invitees in order of importance.
Tutorial (How-to):
1. Decide on the guest count and divide it in half to both families
2. Establish priority with families
3. Create rules to make a cut
4. Determine whether children are invited
5. Assume 20% of your invited guests will not be able to attend

column4: You don't have to be a genius to make one. It's free and super simple. Start by adding the story of how you met and got engaged. The other essential info like venue details and hotels can come later.
Tutorial (How-to):
1. Love story to share how you met and fell in love
2. Introduce wedding party
3. Wedding details: Where and when you'll wed
4. Gift guidance: The shops and sites you've registered at
5. Schedule a date for publish

column4: You don't have to finish your registry list all in one day. Take your time but start now. And make sure you add all your registry links to your wedding website so guests know where you’re registered!
Tutorial (How-to):
1. Asses what you already have, and separate what you need from what you want
2. Decide how much you want to register for
3. Select items from stores and websites
4. Share your registion with invitees

column4: Find gorgeous invitation photos (search by color and style) in our gallery and save all of your favorites to your planner so that you can start to get an idea as to how you want your invites to look.
Tutorial (How-to):
1. Know wedding color and style
2. Shape and Size
3. Legible text and don't crowd the card

column4: You might want to start with fewer rooms and then add more if needed (some hotels require you to pay for rooms that go un-booked). Also, don’t forget to add hotel contact info to your wedding website!
Tutorial (How-to):
1. Estimate your rooms and ask hotels if the number makes sense
2. Make sure the payment policy before you block the rooms
3. Check the details of check-in, check-out time, transportation schedule if needed

column4: The first impression that guests will receive of your wedding will come from the invitations.Designers help you embed your unique stories into stationery.
Tutorial (How-to):
1. Share your saved photos with the designers
2. Confirm the designs, paper, printing options and make payment
3. Provide final wording and review proofs

column4: If you have a designer in mind (local or online), now is the time to order. Going the DIY route? Buy the supplies and start working. You'll want to mail them between six and eight months beforehand.
Tutorial (How-to):
1. Order extra 10
2. Oder stamps

column4: Make your final design picks and order those invites. You’ll finalize the wording at this time too. Also think about how you want to address them (calligraphy?) and don’t forget the stamps!
Tutorial (How-to):
1. Order extra 10
2. Oder stamps

column4: This is one of those milestones that makes the planning you've done so far feel really real! Get them out by the six month mark (more like eight months if you have a lot of out-of-town guests).
Tutorial (How-to):
1. Compile list of names and addresses for all invitees
2. Book a calligrapher if you prefer

column4: Get them out by the three-month mark. If you don't want the post office to add a giant stamp across the front of the envelope, you can ask to have them hand-canceled.
Tutorial (How-to):
1. Take a completely assembled invitations
2. Buy stamps for invitation and response envelopes

column4: A vintage car? A horse-drawn carriage, or a bicycle built for two? Make excitement and convenience.
Tutorial (How-to):
1. Arrange date, time, and locations of pickup and drop-off points
2. Select type and number of vehicles rented
3. Book shuttle services / arrange cars to take out-of-town guests
4. Confirm total cost including gas and mileage, deposit, overtime fee and refund policies
5. Schedule payment and sign contract
6. Provide drivers with directions, addresses and contacts

column4: You could go the traditional route and get a blank book or you could get really unique here. Look through our gallery of ideas and get the supplies you need to make it, or DIY it.
Tutorial (How-to): 1. Purchase guest book and pens

column4: If you’re making them, start working on them. This is also the time to order any packaging supplies.
Tutorial (How-to):
1. Purchase/DIY favors
2. Compose message attached to favor

column4: Programs not only help guide guests through the ceremony, but make charming moments.
Tutorial (How-to):
1. Save program photos and wording online
2. Draft one with your style

column4: If the gifts don't already come packaged, think about how you want them to look when you give them out. Also decide when you're going to give them out (the rehearsal dinner is a popular option).
Tutorial (How-to):
1. Set budget
2. Choose something useful and timeless 
3. Buy gifts and wrap them with thank-yous
4. Decide when to present the gifts

column4: Confirm the final guest party on the wedding day
Tutorial (How-to):
1. Keep aware someone will not attend and some will neglect the RSVP
2. Make follow-up calls to invitees who haven't responded
3. Notify the final number to caterer, venues, planner, cake baker

column4: Seating assignments isn’t exactly an easy task. It's better to work the experienced ones, i.e. your parents, officiants and your married friends.
Tutorial (How-to):
1. Ask parents and fiance about any minefields
2. Ask officiant about seating during ceremony
3. Make it flexible

column4: If you ordered escort cards, it's time to pick them up and organize them. If you're doing the DIY route, then now is the time to start working on them.
Tutorial (How-to):
1. If you order escort cards, make sure you have extra 10 
2. If you DIY escort cards, you shall start now. Keep in mind, you need extra 10 for in case

column4: Ideally, you should try to get them done within two months of your wedding.
Tutorial (How-to):
1. Buy thank you cards
2. Find a blue or black ink pen with which you are comfortable writing
3. Address cards
4. Plan to write your notes as soon after you get gifts 
5. Add a brief comment about the gift you received
6. Add your couple's names and return address
7. Schedule the mailing

column4: Now that you've met with a few, it's time to make a decision and book. Call references first (it can't hurt to double-check), then request a contract and review it for all the critical points.
Tutorial (How-to):
1. Decide your wedding style and service range, including copyrights
2. Research photographers with their real albums
3. Interview the finalists with finance, and check their availability and equipments
4. Book photographers and confirm the payment schedule and insurance policy

column4: They're an extra cost but an engagement photo shoot is well worth the money. Why? Besides the fact you'll get great photos, you'll feel more comfortable having a camera pointed at you on the day of.
Tutorial (How-to):
1. Schedue engagement
2. Connect stylists with photographers
3. Take weather and season into consideration
4. Confirm photo delivery time

column4: A wedding video captures what the photos can't -- like your father's speech, your first dance, or your dress in motion. Research the pros, read our tips, and set up time to meet with your favorites.
Tutorial (How-to):
1. Decide your wedding style and service range, including copyrights, music
2. Research videographers with their sample videos
3. Interview the finalists with finance, and check their availability and equipments
4. Book videographers and confirm payment schedule and insurance policy

column4: Make sure every loved ones has a picture with you on the day.
Tutorial (How-to):
1. Getting ready
2. Before the bride and groom see each other
3. Important moments

column4: From room decor to personal accessories, you will love these flowers along the day.
Tutorial (How-to):
1. Save photos online and on magazines
2. Ask around if anyone has allergies to particular flowers.

column4: A qualified florist can help you narrow down your options, custom-design bouquets and display for you within the budget.
Tutorial (How-to):
1. Interview 3-5 florists and see their samples
2. Share saved photos and your wedding theme color with florists
3. Select all floral items and designs
4. Give table, aisle, gazebo sizes 
5. Schedule payment and sign contract
6. Confirm date, time, delivery and locations with florist

1. Save photos online and on magazines
2. Consider enhance some by candles, lanterns, etc

column4: Ask friends,family to join the fun projects!
Tutorial (How-to):
1. Save decor photos
2. Check how to make them real
3. Invite others to join the projects
4. Don't make the schedule stressful

column4: Ask friends,family to join the fun projects!
Tutorial (How-to):
1. Save decor photos
2. Check how to make them real
3. Invite others to join the projects
4. Don't make the schedule stressful

column4: Upgrade your decoration now!
Tutorial (How-to):
1. Ask venues for referrals and quatity estimation
2. Check their inventory, delivery, insurance policy
3. Schedule payment and sign contract

column4: The shower/bachelorette party is also a party for the bride and her closest female relatives and friends, where she is "showered" with love, good wishes, and gifts.
Tutorial (How-to):
1. Pick a date
2. Compile a guest list
3. Choose venue, theme, menu and decor

column4: Laid-back and casual? Or more formal? Look for rehearsal dinner sites in your area and provide the host with contact information for your attendants and any other guests.
Tutorial (How-to):
1. Pick a date, venue, menu and decor
2. Invite your guests
3. Compose toast to thank guests

column4: If you dread the idea of all eyes on you during the first dance, you might want to consider dance lessons. (Also makes for a fun date night in the midst of all the planning!)
Tutorial (How-to):
1. Choosing a dance style and song
2. Be patient when learning
3. Practice in the right shoes
4. Be consistent with your appointments

column4: Because you might not have time for it on the wedding day (it oftentimes feels like a blur), use this time to really catch up with everyone and welcome friends and family.
Tutorial (How-to):
1. Meet and greet
2. Exchange gifts
3. Toast
4. Remind friendly about the day-of

column4: A welcome party is a is hands-down a great way to get all your guests mixing and mingling early! It can replace a traditional rehearsal dinner or be added on to the end of one.
Tutorial (How-to):
1. Meet and greet
2. Exchange gifts
3. Toast
4. Remind friendly about the day-of things

column4: Music helps set the mood for the entire wedding, and highlights certain moments.
Tutorial (How-to):
1. Interview 3-5 finalists
2. Ask their suggestions to fit your wedding
3. Ask if they will be the master of reception
4. Confirm payment schedule and sign the contract

column4: Traditional organ? Or modern DJ music? Put together a budget for your ceremony music and then start your search.
Tutorial (How-to):
1. Interview 2-3 options
2. Ask their suggestions to fit your wedding
3. Check if they need sheet music or equipment
4. Confirm payment schedule and sign the contract
5. Go through the details with site coordinator and officiant, i.e. timing

column4: Treat your guests with a set of delicious food.
Tutorial (How-to):
1. Ask your venue if they recommend someones
2. Make sure who is the chef on your day
3. Ask to see the operating license or health permit
4. Confirm the style: seated, buffet, station and cocktail
5. Ask for menu suggestions to fit your budget, style, season and allergy concerns
6. Ask if anything is free, i.e. sodas, corkage fee
7. Schedule the payment and sign the contract

column4: Your cake design is your chance to drive home your favorite colors, flowers, and theme -- not to mention flavors! Look at tons of photos and save your favorites to show your cake baker.
Tutorial (How-to):
1. Save the photos to show cake bakers later
2. Don't feel like cake is the only option. How about pie, ice cream, or even donuts?

column4: Once you've had a chance to taste all the samples (yum), and talk design, decide on a baker. Request a contract and make sure all the details are there (like flavor and fillings). Then book!
Tutorial (How-to):
1. Take catering menu, allergy history into consideration 
2. Schedule cake tastings 
3. Show your saved photos to them and check their previous work
4. Check if the venue/cake baker requires a cake-cutting fee
5. Confirm the delivery and rental items
5. Schedule the payment and sign the contract

column4: Cake tasting time!
Tutorial (How-to):
1. Visit cake bakers to taste cakes
2. Choose cake flavors
3. Choose a topper (online / in-store)

column4: Among the big glass-clinking moments, there's the rehearsal dinner and the reception dinner. Plan to say a few words. Look through our list of ideas and then print out or come up with your own toast.
Tutorial (How-to):
1. Clarify the relation with the couple
2. Share an anecdote
3. Offer a compliment

column4: If it's a nondenominational person, there will probably be a contract and a deposit involved. This is also the time to start scheduling any premarital counseling sessions (if you're doing them).
Tutorial (How-to):
1. If you and your fiance(e) belong to the same church or synagogue, you're in luck! 
2. Choose the type of wedding ceremony you want
3. Ask availability for rehearsal and wedding day
4. Ask services and fees, and watch them perform ceremonies to see if it's what you want
5. Ask for the sermon or an overview
6. Ask any restriction, i.e. music, attire,etc
7. Confirm payment schedule and sign the contract

column4: Go over any detailed ceremony additions you want to make sure they're okay.
Tutorial (How-to):
1. Schedule a follow-up meeting or phone call with your officiant to go over ceremony timing and details.
2. Finalize your ceremony readings and who will be reading (and to ask them)
3. Write your vows
4. Finalize the processional order

column4: Ask friends, family, and even travel agents to help you find your ideal vacation spot. Narrow it down to your top three to five spots and then start keeping an eye out for flights.
Tutorial (How-to):
1. Figure out the date, hotels and transportaion
2. Acquire guide books
3. Book activities
